descriptions:
Here is a possible abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Egalitarianism: Forms, Processes, Comparisons

This project undertakes a comprehensive and innovative study of egalitarianism, examining its diverse forms, processes, and values across different cultural contexts. Through a combination of library-based global comparative research and field ethnographic studies, we will investigate the heterogeneity of egalitarian structures, processes, and values, and develop a decentering orientation to account for the complexities and contradictions of egalitarian practices.

Our research will integrate library and field studies to understand how egalitarianism is imagined, practiced, and valued in different societies. We will develop a comparative method that is responsive to historical, socio-political, and geo-ecological circumstances, and open to diverse conceptions and imaginations of egalitarianism. Our study will explore perennial questions such as the role of the state, religion, economic distribution, and scale, and examine how these factors shape egalitarian practices in Europe and beyond.

By focusing on the cultural aspects of egalitarianism, this project will provide new insights into the ways in which egalitarian values are negotiated, practiced, and contested in different contexts. Ultimately, our goal is to develop a nuanced understanding of egalitarianism as a cultural value, and to contribute to the development of more inclusive and equitable societies.

Title: Egalitarianism: Forms, Processes, Comparisons

This project undertakes a comprehensive exploration of egalitarianism, examining its diverse forms, processes, and values across cultures and societies. Through a library-based global comparative study and field ethnographic research, we will investigate the heterogeneity of egalitarian structures, practices, and values, decentering dominant orientations to reveal the complexities of egalitarianism as a cultural phenomenon. Our research aims to integrate library and field studies, developing a novel comparative method that is responsive to historical, socio-political, and geo-ecological contexts. We will examine the role of the state, religion, economic distribution, and scale in shaping egalitarian practices, and address perennial questions in the field. Our research sites will span Europe and beyond, allowing for a nuanced understanding of egalitarianism in diverse settings.

By recognizing egalitarian practices and processes as cultural values, this project will provide a richer understanding of the complexities and contradictions inherent in egalitarianism. We will confront the challenges of force, contradictions, and limitations that arise in egalitarian systems, and develop a method that is open to varied conceptions and imagination. Ultimately, this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the forms and practices of egalitarianism, informing theoretical and practical approaches to promoting equality and social justice.

Here is a 266-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Egalitarianism: Forms, Processes, Comparisons

This project proposes a groundbreaking, library-based global comparative study complemented by field ethnographic research to investigate the heterogeneity of egalitarian structures, processes, and values. By adopting a decentering orientation, we aim to move beyond dominant Western conceptions of egalitarianism and develop a comparative method that is responsive to diverse historical, socio-political, and geo-ecological contexts. Our research focuses on the complexities of egalitarian practices and processes, seeking to understand how they are negotiated, contested, and reimagined in various cultural settings.

Through a comparative analysis of egalitarian forms and practices in Europe and beyond, we will explore perennial questions related to the role of the state, religion, economic distribution, and scale. By examining the cultural values underpinning egalitarianism, we will delve into the contradictions, limitations, and forces that shape these values in different contexts. Our approach is characterized by an openness to diverse conceptions and imaginations of egalitarianism, allowing us to capture the richness and variability of egalitarian practices worldwide.

The project's key proposition is that egalitarian practices and processes are cultural values that deserve in-depth comparative analysis. By integrating library and field studies, we will develop a nuanced understanding of egalitarianism in its various forms and manifestations. Our research will contribute to the development of a more inclusive and culturally sensitive understanding of egalitarianism, with implications for social theory, policy, and practice.
